results.title: World Series Debating: That Football is Stupid
results.creator_credit: Andrew Denton, Ted Robinson, Joe Murray, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Wendy Harmer
results.brief_description: One of the most popular events of the annual Melbourne Comedy Festival, the debate was filmed over several years by ABC TV. Campbell McComas introduces two teams of 3 people consisting of Wendy Harmer, Edmund Capon, Lex Marinos, HG Nelson, Laurie Lawrence, Andrew Denton. The topic of this debate is that football is stupid.

results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Francis Jupurrula Kelly, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: Landline: Stripping the Myth
results.brief_description:
‘Landline’ is the ABC’s national rural issues program.

This episode investigates the conventionally accepted history of the invention and development of the combine harvester. The widely held belief that a young Victorian, Hugo Victor McKay, was the inventor of the world’s first such machine is exposed as a myth.

First broadcast on 13th March, 2005.

results.title: Blue Murder: Part 2
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Based on the events that led to the Royal Commission on Police Corruption in New South Wales, ‘Blue Murder’ is a riveting and exceptionally well executed thriller about police corruption and gangland criminal activity in 1980s Australia.
Richard Roxburgh is outstanding as Roger Rogerson, the larrikin police chief who built a lucrative ‘alternative’ career based on bribery, drug money and murder. Tony Martin is Neddy Smith, one of Australia’s most notorious underworld thugs.
Rogerson and Smith’s activities are threatened when a young police officer, Michael Drury (Steve Bastoni), declines a bribe offered to him by Rogerson. From that moment on, ‘Blue Murder’ depicts how Drury’s involvement in acting as an informer on Rogerson’s activities led to increasingly desperate and murderous acts by both police and crims.
Acclaimed internationally as a landmark television mini-series, ‘Blue Murder’ was for years unable to be screened in NSW or available for view on video in Australia due to elements of the story being seen as prejudicial to legal trials in NSW and Federal Courts.
Cast also inlcudes Alex Dimitriades, Peter Phelps and John Hargreaves.
First broadcast (outside NSW) September 21st, 1995.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment

results.title: After the Tsunami: Schools Helping Schools in Aceh
results.creator_credit: Barry Mitchell and ABC Asia Pacific
results.brief_description: On 26th December 2004, a massive earthquake in the Indian Ocean caused the tsunamis that devastated many nearby coastal areas, with no area more profoundly affected than the province of Aceh in Indonesia. Over 150,000 people were killed, many of them school students, their parents and teachers, and many schools were partly, or completely destroyed. Governments all over the world offered money and aid, but even small organisations can have a big impact. The International Baccalaureate Organisation set up its ‘schools to schools’ program especially to connect schools in tsunami-affected regions with schools in Australia and other countries. This documentary shows how schools in Indonesia have started to pick up the pieces, and how the IBO is helping to rebuild.

results.title: Catalyst: Fire Storm
results.creator_credit: Andrew Holland, Ian Cuming and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
A scientific investigation into the causes of the catastrophic Canberra bushfires of January 2003 where 474 homes were destroyed and four lives lost. Includes interviews with residents, scientists, environmentalists and fire-fighters.
Episode from the ABC TV series ‘Catalyst’ presented and narrated by Karina Kelly.

results.title: Quantum: A Green Dinosaur
results.creator_credit: Gail Jarvis, Cathy Johnson and ABC-TV (Australia). Science Unit
results.brief_description:
In 1994 park rangers in the Wollemi National Park, New South Wales, discovered a grove of ancient trees thought to have been extinct for 60 million years. The location of the thirty-eight adult trees, identified as a genus of the family Araucariaceae, has been kept a secret from all but a handful of people to protect them from sightseers and those who would collect seeds to sell on the black market. Three years later Cathy Johnson is the first and only journalist to have been to the site of the Wollemi pines - but not without having been blindfolded during the helicopter journey in and out.
Broadcast on ABC-TV 10 July 1997 as part of the program ‘Quantum’ and produced with the assistance of NSW National Parks and Wildlife service.

results.title: A Big Country: The Legend of Jimmy Governor
results.brief_description:
Episode of ABC TV series ‘A Big Country’ exploring the real life story of Jimmy Governor, as compared to his fictional counterpart, Jimmie Blacksmith, in the novel and film, ‘The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith’. Includes interviews with author, Thomas Keneally, and film director, Fred Schepisi, on location during the making of the film.
Broadcast on ABC TV in April 1978. Reporter: Kenyon Castle. Narrator: Bob Plasto.

results.title: Four Corners: The Moonlight State
results.creator_credit: Shaun Hoyt and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Despite denials by the Minister for Local Government Russ Hinze, Police Commissioner Terence Lewis, and Police Minister, Bill Gunn, widespread police corruption is evident throughout Queensland. Brothels masquerading as massage parlours with illegal gambling inhouse and drug trafficking are shown. Persons prominent in the criminal activities are named. This program was a major contributor to the setting up of the Fitzgerald Enquiry into Corruption in Queensland. Presenter: Andrew Olle. Reporter: Chris Masters.
Episode of the ABC TV program Four Corners, aired 11/5/1987.
